statements.text: Nazi Germany invaded Poland in 1939, prompting the Allied powers to declare war.
The Axis powers formed around Nazi Germany, Italy, and Japan, opposing the Allied powers.
The United Kingdom endured months of bombing in the Blitz by Nazi Germany.
The Soviet Union signed a nonaggression pact with Nazi Germany shortly before the invasion.
The United States initially stayed neutral, supplying material aid to the Allied powers.
Japan expanded across East Asia and the Pacific as a member of the Axis powers.
The Battle of Britain saw the United Kingdom resist intense air attacks from Nazi Germany.
Allied powers coordinated strategy in meetings between the United States and the United Kingdom.
The Soviet Union suffered enormous casualties while pushing Nazi Germany back on the Eastern Front.
In North Africa, Axis powers fought Allied forces for control of vital Mediterranean supply routes.
Japan attacked Pearl Harbor in 1941, bringing the United States fully into World War II.
Following Pearl Harbor, the United States, United Kingdom, and Soviet Union opposed the Axis powers.
The United States became an industrial arsenal for the Allied powers, producing ships and aircraft.
The United Kingdom relied on convoys as Nazi Germany used submarines to cut Allied shipping.
On the Eastern Front, the Soviet Union launched large offensives that steadily weakened Nazi Germany.
In the Pacific theater, the United States advanced toward Japan while Allied powers fought elsewhere.
Japan's occupation policies in Asia imposed harsh rule, provoking resistance movements and complicating Allied planning.
The Axis powers lost momentum as setbacks in North Africa and the Soviet Union mounted.
Allied powers used strategic bombing against Nazi Germany and Japan to damage industry and infrastructure.
The Soviet Union's victory at Stalingrad marked a decisive turning point against Nazi Germany.
The United States and United Kingdom coordinated landings in Europe to open fronts against Nazi Germany.
Italy's surrender weakened the Axis powers in Europe, forcing Nazi Germany to defend longer coastlines.
Japan suffered major naval defeats in the Pacific as the United States gained carrier superiority.
Within the Allied powers, disagreements still arose over postwar boundaries and influence in Eastern Europe.
The Soviet Union advanced into Eastern Europe, while Allied powers pushed westward toward Nazi Germany.
As Axis powers collapsed, many occupied territories regained formal governments under Allied supervision or influence.
Japan faced bombing and naval blockade by the United States in the final months.
The United Kingdom emerged victorious but economically strained compared with the United States.
The Soviet Union extended influence over Eastern Europe after defeating Nazi Germany.
The United States became a leading global power as Nazi Germany and Japan were defeated.
War crimes trials by Allied powers prosecuted leaders from Nazi Germany and Japan.
The Axis powers left devastated cities and displaced populations across Europe and parts of Asia.
Allied powers promoted new international institutions, with the United States playing a central organizing role.
Nazi Germany's defeat ended its regime, while the Soviet Union solidified control nearby.
Japan's surrender followed the atomic bombings and Soviet entry into the war in Asia.
The United Kingdom, United States, and Soviet Union emerged as central actors in postwar diplomacy.
World War II reshaped power, with the United States and Soviet Union becoming superpowers.
Allied powers helped establish the United Nations as a forum to prevent future global conflicts.
The Axis powers were dissolved as military alliances, leaving their former members occupied or closely monitored.
World War II's devastation encouraged cooperation between former Allied powers despite ideological tensions.
